questions.text: Ramya, a 23-year-old female, presents with difficulty in swallowing both liquids and solids. You decided to do a barium swallow. The following image is obtained. What is the probable diagnosis based on the image given?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The given clinical scenario, along with the barium swallow, shows a distended oesophagus followed by thinning of the contrast column of the barium, giving a bird beak appearance and is suggestive of achalasia cardia.

  • Achalasia is a primary oesophageal motility disorder characterised by the absence of oesophageal peristalsis and impaired relaxation of the lower oesophageal sphincter (LES)in response to swallowing.
  • These abnormalities cause a functional obstruction at the gastroesophageal junction.
  • Dysphagia liquids > solids

Oesophageal Manometry Shows:

  • Incomplete LES relaxation in response to swallowing
  • High resting LES pressure
  • Absent oesophageal peristalsis

Explanation of other options:

Trachea-oesophageal fistula (Option B):

The given image shows a barium swallow of the oesophagus. There is opacification of the tracheobronchial tree by contrast. This occurs when the contrast passes from the oesophagus to the trachea, as occurs in TEF.

Typically presents in neonates with drooling and choking during feeds; imaging shows air in the oesophagus and trachea.

Carcinoma oesophagus (Option C) :

Barium swallow irregularity, narrowing oesophageal lumen with mucosal lumen and shouldered margins. It is suggestive of oesophageal carcinoma. It may mimic achalasia radiologically (pseudoachalasia), but generally presents in older patients; irregular narrowing is more typical than smooth tapering.

Eosinophilic oesophagitis (Option D):


Trachealization of the oesophagus is seen in eosinophilic esophagitis. Common in allergic individuals; barium studies may show ringed oesophagus (feline oesophagus).

questions.text: A patient presents with progressive difficulty in swallowing solid food. A barium swallow examination was performed, and the following radiological image was obtained. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The given barium image shows a narrowing of the contrast column in the mid and distal oesophagus.This, along with a history of corrosive acid poisoning, points to a diagnosis of corrosive stricture.

Corrosive strictures typically result from ingestion of acidic or alkaline substances that lead to:

  • Inflammation, ulceration, and fibrosis of the oesophageal wall
  • Subsequent fibrotic healing, causing long-segment narrowing

The typical imaging appearance on barium swallow is:

  • Smooth or irregular long-segment narrowing
  • Often in the upper or mid-oesophagus
  • No shouldering or abrupt cutoff as seen in malignancy

Explanation of other options:

Tracheoesophageal fistula (Option A):


The above image shows a barium swallow of the oesophagus. There is opacification of the tracheobronchial tree by contrast. This occurs when the contrast passes from the oesophagus to the trachea, as occurs in TEF, whereas the given X-ray shows a narrowing of the contrast column in the mid and distal oesophagus. This, along with a history of corrosive acid poisoning, points to a diagnosis of corrosive stricture.

Oesophageal carcinoma (Option B): Barium swallow irregularity, narrowing of the oesophageal lumen with mucosal lumen and shouldered margins. It is suggestive of oesophageal carcinoma, whereas the given X-ray shows a narrowing of the contrast column in the mid and distal oesophagus. This, along with a history of corrosive acid poisoning, points to a diagnosis of corrosive stricture.


Achalasia cardia (Option C): The barium swallow shows a distended oesophagus followed by thinning of the contrast column of the barium giving a bird beak appearance, and is suggestive of achalasia cardia, whereas the given X-ray shows a narrowing of the contrast column in the mid and distal oesophagus. This, along with a history of corrosive acid poisoning, points to a diagnosis of corrosive stricture.


Key Takeaways:

  • Corrosive strictures are a common late complication of caustic ingestion.
  • Appear as long, smooth or irregular strictures on barium swallow.
  • Shouldered, short, irregular strictures point toward carcinoma.

questions.text: A 63-year-old male presented with progressive dysphagia for solids, loss of appetite and loss of weight. A barium swallow is advised. What is the most likely diagnosis based on the following barium swallow images?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The given barium image shows barium swallow irregularity narrowing the oesophageal lumen with mucosal lumenand shouldered margins.
  • It is suggestive of oesophageal
  • Radiologic signs of oesophageal carcinoma include:
    • Short-segment irregular narrowing
    • Shouldering effect at the lesion margins
    • Mucosal destruction and shouldering
    • Abrupt transition zone and lack of tapering are seen in benign conditions
    • Most common site: Lower third of the oesophagus

Explanation of other options:

Achalasia cardia (Option A): The barium swallow shows a distended oesophagus followed by thinning of the contrast column of the barium, giving a bird beak appearance and is suggestive of achalasia cardia.


Diffuse oesophageal spasm (Option C): The barium swallow image shows a Corkscrew appearance of the oesophagus, suggestive of Diffuse oesophageal spasm.


GERD-Feline oesophagus (Option D): is seen in chronic GERD, whereas the given X-ray shows barium swallow irregularity, narrowing oesophageal lumen with mucosal lumen and shouldered margins is suggestive of oesophageal carcinoma.

questions.text: What is the investigation of choice to determine local Invasion In oesophageal carcinoma (T staging)?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Endoscopic Ultrasound: Determines Local Invasion in oesophageal Carcinoma (T staging)
  • Endoscopic ultrasound (EUS) is a valuable imaging technique that combines endoscopy and ultrasound to provide detailed imaging of the oesophagus and surrounding structures. It is commonly used in the diagnosis and staging of oesophageal carcinoma.
  • The endoscope is equipped with an ultrasound transducer that provides high-resolution images of the layers of the oesophageal wall. This helps in determining the location and extent of the tumour within the oesophageal wall.

EUS showing Squamous cell Carcinoma of the oesophagus

Explanation of other options:

Transabdominal USG (Option A): Has no role in determining the Local Invasion In oesophageal carcinoma, as it is a deep structure.

The CECT (Option B) and MRI (Option D) can detect oesophageal carcinoma, but it has no role in determining the Local Invasion In oesophageal carcinoma, as it is a deep structure.

questions.text: Identify the diagnosis based on the given abdominal radiograph of an infant presenting with abdominal distension and failure to pass meconium since birth:-
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • In the image given above, there is the presence of 2 air-fluid levels (double bubble) within the abdomen.
  • This is suggestive of duodenal atresia as the one air fluid level is of fundic gas shadow, and the other is of the first part of the duodenum.
  • The double bubble sign represents the dilatation of the proximal duodenum and stomach. It can also be detected antenatally by ultrasound.

Causes of the double bubble sign:

  • Congenital obstruction - duodenal atresia (associated with Down syndrome)
  • Midgut volvulus
  • External compression of the duodenum

Explanation of other options:

Infantile Hyper-tropic Pyloric stenosis (Option A): Shows single gastric bubble with no distal obstruction and visibly thickened pylorus on ultrasound ("target sign").


Jejunal atresia (Option C) is a congenital anomaly characterised by obliteration of the lumen of the jejunum. The site of the atresia can be anywhere from the ligament of Treitz to the jejunoileal junction. The classic radiographic sign of jejunal atresia is the triple bubble sign of a proximal obstruction; it is equivalent to the double bubble sign of duodenal atresia with a third bubble caused by jejunal distention with air.


Tracheo-oesophagal fistula (Option D):


The above image shows a barium swallow of the oesophagus. There is opacification of the tracheobronchial tree by contrast. This occurs when the contrast passes from the oesophagus to the trachea, as occurs in TEF, whereas the given image shows the double bubble sign.

questions.text: An 18-day-old child is brought to the OPD with complaints of recurrent vomiting. On evaluation, an olive-shaped mass was found on abdominal examination. A USG is advised and shows the following signs. Identify the condition associated.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The given USG shows the cervix/ antral nipple sign and is seen in the case of Infantile hypertrophic pyloric stenosis (IHPS).

  • Firstborn male child > 3 weeks.
  • Non-bilious vomiting, palpable olive-like mass at the epigastrium.
  • The child has hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis with paradoxical aciduria.
  • The common cause of gastric outlet obstruction (GOO), especially in first-born males between 2-6 weeks of age.

Ultrasound (USG) Findings:

  • Muscle Hypertrophy:
    • Thickening of the pyloric muscle is a hallmark feature (> 3 mm).
  • Pyloric Length:
    • Elongation of the pyloric channel is often observed. (>16 mm)
  • Double-Track or Railroad Track Sign:
    • Appearance of two parallel, echogenic (bright) lines on either side of the lumen.
    • Gives the characteristic "double-track" or "railroad track" appearance.

Explanation of other options:

Intussusception (Option A) is a condition in which one segment of the intestine "telescopes" inside another, causing an intestinal obstruction (blockage). It will show a claw sign on barium studies and target sign on USG, whereas the given USG shows cervix sign, which is seen in the case of IHPS.


In the case of ileocecal tuberculosis (Option B), shows a gooseneck deformity. Gooseneck deformity occurs due to contracted, cicatrised, and pulled-up cecum as well as straightening of the terminal ileum, whereas the given USG shows a cervix sign, which is seen in the case of IHPS.


Hirschsprung disease (Option D) shows narrowing of the distal-most colon and proximal dilation of the colon, whereas the given USG shows a cervix sign, which is seen in the case of IHPS.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male patient presents to the emergency department with severe abdominal pain and distension. An erect chest X-ray is performed, and is shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The above X-ray clearly shows the presence of subdiaphragmatic free gas and is indicative of pneumoperitoneum.
  • IOC → CT scan
  • Best x-ray view → Chest X-ray erect
  • Air under the diaphragm is seen
  • 2nd best view (X-ray) → Left lateral decubitus view

The radiographic signs of the perforation are given below:

  • Air under the central tendon of the diaphragm is known as the cupola sign
  • Free air in the hepatorenal pouch is known as Doge's cap sign
  • Air on either side of the bowel is known as Rigler's sign
  • The presence of extraluminal air is known as the Tell-e-tale triangle sign
  • The visibility of the lateral umbilical ligament is known as the inverted V sign, the medial umbilical ligament is known as the urachus sign, and the falciform ligament can be visible as well, known as the ligament teres sign.

This is an emergency, requiring prompt surgical intervention.

Explanation of other options:

Appendicitis (Option A) on USG shows a long, narrow, tubular, inflamed structure in RIF. In case of appendicular rupture, it may present with hollow viscus perforation.

Pancreatitis (Option B) shows the clinical feature of upper abdominal pain radiating to the back, along with the X-ray showing a colon cutoff sign.

Pneumothorax (Option D) refers to the presence of gas (air) in the pleural space; there is accumulation of intrapleural gas in the thoracic cavity. X-ray chest shows a large hyperlucent area with no vascular markings.

questions.text: Which of the following is the likely diagnosis of the given radiograph?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The above fluoroscopic image shows air in the dilated loops of the proximal bowel, with eccentric or concentric narrowing of the descending duodenum, confirming the diagnosis of ileal atresia.
  • Ileal atresia is a congenital anomaly in which part of the ileum is narrow or completely missing.
  • Presents with bilious vomiting and abdominal distension in neonates.
  • Prenatal polyhydramnios may be seen
  • Confirmed by contrast enema or small bowel contrast study
  • Treatment is surgical (resection and anastomosis)

On barium enema

  • Microcolon
  • Apple peel appearance
  • Multiple air-fluid levels-"Triple bubble" or "step-ladder" appearance may be seen, depending on the level

Explanation of other options:

Small Bowel Obstruction (Option A) presents with diffuse abdominal pain and radiologically shows a Stepladder Pattern, dilated loops of small bowel proximal, predominantly central dilated loops, and three instances of dilatation > 2.5 - 3 cm.


Crohn's disease (Option C) is an inflammatory bowel diseases that give characteristic features on imaging.

In Crohn's disease, the characteristic sign is the presence of skip lesions and discrete ulcers. The features on barium small bowel follow-through include aphthous mucosal ulcers or deep ulcers (>3 mm depth). Longitudinal fissures with transverse stripes leading to a cobblestone appearance. Chronic it may lead to sinus tracts and fistulae.



The features seen on CT include: The fat halo sign depicts submucosal fat deposition. Bowel wall thickening, engorgement of the vasa recta giving Comb sign. Perienteric fat stranding with the presence of strictures and fistulae.


Ulcerative colitis (Option D): It is also known as pancolitis, as it involves the whole rectum with oedema of even the terminal ileum. The features on fluoroscopy include: Mucosal granularity is seen with button-shaped ulcers. In chronic cases, the bowel becomes featureless with the loss of normal haustral markings, luminal narrowing, and bowel shortening known as lead pipe colon.

The features of CT include:- In chronic cases, submucosal fat deposition is observed, particularly in the rectum, resulting in a fat halo sign.



Key Takeaways:

  • Ileal atresia is a common cause of neonatal intestinal obstruction.
  • Contrast radiograph shows dilated loops with abrupt cut-off.
  • Immediate surgical management is required.

questions.text: A 11 month old child presented with recurrent abdominal pain and blood in stools. On examination a mass can be felt in lumbar region. A barium enema study was done. Diagnosis is?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The barium enema image shows a classic "coiled spring" appearance, which is characteristic of intussusception.
  • It is a condition in which one segment of the intestine telescopes inside another, causing an intestinal obstruction.
    • It usually presents with nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain with blood in stools: "currant jelly".
    • A palpable abdominal massmay be found on physical examination.
    • On X-ray: Meniscus sign
    • On USG: Target sign/ Doughnut Sign
    • On Barium enema:
    • Claw sign/ Pincer sign
    • Coiled spring appearance

Duodenal atresia (Option A) shows the double bubble sign representing the dilatation of the proximal duodenum and stomach. The given barium image shows the presence of the claw sign.

Malrotation (Option C): "Reverse double bubble" sign on upper gastrointestinal contrast study, indicating duodenal obstruction, with the duodenojejunal junction located on the right side of the spine rather than the left.

Volvulus (Option D): "Coffee-bean sign" on abdominal imaging studies such as ultrasound or CT, indicating the twisting of bowel loops around the mesenteric axis.

questions.text: What is the sign being depicted and the diagnosis of the image given below?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The given image is characteristic of ileocecal tuberculosis, which exhibits a "gooseneck" deformity.
  • Goose neck deformity occurs due to contracted, cicatrised, and pulled-up cecum as well as straightening of the terminal ileum.

Radiological signs seen in ileocecal TB are :

  • Fleischner's sign/ inverted umbrella sign: Wide, patulous ileocecal valve with narrow terminal ileum.
  • Stierlin's sign: Rapid emptying of the cecum with the passage of barium from the terminal ileum to the ascending colon, due to chronic mucosal irritation.
  • String sign: A persistently narrowed segment of the intestine due to inflammation or formation of stricture.
  • Pseudokidney sign: Pulling of the ileocecal region in the subhepatic position.
  • The IOC for intestinal TB is CT enterography, and the hallmark feature is the presence of necrotic mesenteric nodes.

Explanation of other options:

The Claw sign (Option A) is seen in barium studies in the case of intussusception.


A thumbprint sign (Option C) is seen in ischemic colitis.


Apple core sign (Option D) is seen in the carcinoma colon.

questions.text: A 65-year-old patient presents to the ER with acute abdominal pain and distension. The patient has a history of chronic constipation and previous episodes of abdominal discomfort. Upon physical examination, the abdomen is tympanic to percussion, and the radiograph taken is shown below. What is your most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Abdominal distension, abdominal pain with a chronic history of constipation in an elderly patient, is suggestive of volvulus.The given image showing a coffee bean sign (caused by a grossly distended sigmoid loop with medial apposition of its walls) confirms the diagnosis to be sigmoid volvulus.
  • Volvulus is the twisting of the intestine around its axis. In the case of sigmoid volvulus, twisting occurs at the base of the sigmoid mesocolon.
  • Sigmoid volvulus is the most common type of volvulus. It is usually seen in weak, elderly and hospitalised patients with a history of constipation.

Explanation of other options:

Cecal volvulus (Option A) is seen in young patients, during pregnancy or in patients who have undergone surgery. Radiologically, it shows an embryonic sign.


Large bowel obstruction (Option B) shows characteristic haustrations, and the bowel loops are seen peripherally. The most common cause of LBO is malignancy.


Gastric volvulus (Option D) is characterised by Borchardt's triad consisting of unproductive retching, epigastric pain and distention, and the inability to pass a nasogastric tube.

questions.text: An infant born prematurely at 28 weeks of gestation is admitted to the neonatal intensive care unit. On the 5th day of life, the infant develops abdominal distension, feeding intolerance, and bloody stools. Physical examination reveals tenderness over the abdomen. There is intramural air in the bowel loops on imaging. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The presence of air in bowel loops with prematurity as a risk factor and presentation of bloody stools summarises the diagnosis as necrotising enterocolitis.
  • It is caused by idiopathic inflammation of the intestines, causing abdominal distension and pneumatosis intestinalis.
  • The key features include abdominal distension, feeding intolerance, bloody stools, and systemic signs of sepsis.
  • The hallmark radiological feature is the presence of intramural gas (pneumatosis intestinalis), which is pathognomonic and best seen on abdominal radiographs.

Abdominal radiograph taken from a premature infant with poor feeding and abdominal distension within 10 days of birth.


IHPS (Option A) will give a presentation of a neonate in the 3rd week of life with non-bilious vomiting and USG shows the cervix / antral nipple sign.

Hirschsprung's disease (Option B) is colonic aganglionosis, which presents with meconium ileus for the first 48 hours of life and shows narrowing of the distal-most colon and proximal dilation of the colon.


The annular pancreas (Option D) shows that the double bubble sign represents the dilatation of the proximal duodenum and stomach.

questions.text: A 2-week-old infant presents with recurrent episodes of bilious vomiting and abdominal distension. The infant appears irritable, and on physical examination, there is the presence of an abdominal mass with tenderness. The radiograph of the neonate is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The given radiograph shows a cork screw appearance sign which describes the spiral appearance of the distal duodenum and proximal jejunum seen in midgut volvulus.
  • Midgut volvulus is a paediatric surgical emergency and can be life-threatening, with the majority presenting in infancy with bilious vomiting, abdominal distension, and signs of intestinal obstruction.
  • Urgent surgical repair is required to reduce the volvulus and prevent bowel ischaemia and necrosis.

Explanation of other options:

IHPS (Option A) is an idiopathic hypertrophy of the pylorus, neonates manifest between 6 to 12 weeks of age with typical presentation of non-bilious projectile vomiting and an olive-sized mass in the epigastrium. Ultrasound is the modality of choice and shows the cervix / antral nipple sign. A muscle wall thickness of 3 mm or greater and a pyloric channel length of 14 mm or greater is diagnostic of iHPS.

Intussusception (Option B) is a condition in which one segment of the intestine "telescopes" inside another, causing an intestinal obstruction (blockage). The most common type is ileocolic, which will show the claw sign on barium studies and the target sign on USG.


Duodenal atresia (Option D) shows a characteristic double bubble sign on the abdominal radiograph and presents typically within the first 24-48 hours after birth.

questions.text: Identify the diagnosis based on the CT findings in a patient with diarrhoea.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The CT image depicts marked colonic wall thickening and pericolic fat stranding, with the characteristic accordion sign seen in pseudomembranous colitis, most commonly associated with Clostridium difficile infection, often following recent antibiotic use.
  • The thickened, edematous bowel resembles the folds of an accordion. The hyperemic enhancing mucosa stretched over the thickened submucosal folds produces this accordion appearance.
  • This is also seen when the contrast gets trapped between edematous haustral folds and pseudomembranes of the colon.

An accordion sign is typical for pseudomembranous colitis, but can also be seen in:

  • Ischemic colitis
  • AIDS-related colitis
  • Severe oedema from cirrhosis.

Explanation of other options:

Crohn's disease (Option B): The characteristic sign is the presence of skip lesions and discrete ulcers. On barium small bowel follow-through include- Aphthous mucosal ulcers and Longitudinal fissures with transverse stripes leading to a cobblestone appearance. Chronic it may lead to sinus tracts and fistulae. The features seen on CT include: Fat halo sign and Bowel wall thickening, engorgement of the vasa recta giving Comb sign.




Ulcerative colitis (Option C): It is also known as pancolitis as it involves the whole rectum with oedema of even the terminal ileum. On fluoroscopy, it shows that mucosal granularity is seen with button-shaped ulcers. In chronic cases, the bowel becomes featureless with loss of normal haustral markings, and lead pipe colon.



Celiac disease (Option D): is a T-cell mediated autoimmune chronic gluten intolerance, on CT enteroclysis shows jejunoileal fold pattern reversal and ileal fold thickening.

questions.text: A 34-year-old young male presenting with abdominal pain after sustaining blunt trauma to his abdomen during a road traffic accident has a BP of 120/80 and a pulse of 72 bpm. What is the next best step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

In this patient, since hemodynamics are stable (BP 120/80, pulse 72 bpm), a FAST (Ultrasound scan) is the appropriate next step to quickly identify any free fluid suggestive of internal bleeding.

Ultrasound

  • The Focused Assessment with Sonography in Trauma (FAST) is an ultrasound protocol developed to assess for hemoperitoneum and hemopericardium, and it is the first step in the management of blunt abdominal trauma.
  • It typically involves scanning four areas:
    • right upper quadrant (liver and kidney),
    • left upper quadrant (spleen and kidney),
    • suprapubic region (bladder),
    • pericardial area (heart).
  • eFAST is particularly useful for identifying intra-abdominal haemorrhage, pericardial effusion or tamponade, and pneumothorax, aiding in prompt decision-making and triage of trauma patients.

Explanation of other options:

Diagnostic Peritoneal Tap (Option A) is not used in the current management protocol for abdominal trauma.

The NCCT (Option C) abdomen is not used in the current management protocol of abdominal trauma.

CECT (Option D) is used for the assessment of the source of bleeding in stable patients with abdominal trauma after Ultrasound.

questions.text: A patient presented with a complaint of acute RIF pain. He underwent a CECT abdomen, which is shown below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The given image shows a CECT abdomen of the patient. It shows a long, narrow, tubular, inflamed structure in RIF. This is an inflamed appendix and is highly suggestive of appendicitis.
  • IOC - in children for appendicitis- USG
  • IOC - in adults for appendicitis- CTAbdomen.

USG signs of acute appendicitis:

  • Blind ending, tubular non-compressible structure with a diameter ≥ 7 mm
  • Absent peristalsis
  • Appendicolith
  • Surrounding fluid
  • The graded technique of ultrasound is used

CT signs of acute appendicitis

  • More accurate and sensitive
  • Appendicular diameter > 6mm
  • Failure of the appendix to fill with oral contrast or air till its tip
  • Appendicolith
  • Enhancement of its wall on IV contrast
  • Arrowhead sign- due to mucosal thickening, the air/ contrast will appear conically like an arrowhead.
  • Caecal bar sign- preventing the entry of contrast into the appendix due to thickening.

Explanation of other options:

Intestinal perforation (Option B) shows the presence of subdiaphragmatic free gas and features of shock, whereas the given image shows a narrow tubular inflamed structure suggestive of appendicitis.

Tuberculosis (Option C) shows a gooseneck deformity. Gooseneck deformity occurs due to contracted, cicatrised, and pulled-up cecum as well as straightening of the terminal ileum, whereas the given image shows a narrow tubular inflamed structure suggestive of appendicitis.

Intussusception (Option D) is a condition in which one segment of the intestine "telescopes" inside another, causing an intestinal obstruction (blockage). The most common type is ileocolic, whereas the given image shows a narrow tubular inflamed structure suggestive of appendicitis.

questions.text: Given X-ray indicates obstruction of which of the bowel loops?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The given image shows dilated bowel loops.
  • They are situated in the periphery and show haustrations. This all suggests large bowel obstruction.
  • The haustra do not extend across the full width of the bowel, which is characteristic of the large intestine.
  • The IOC for intestinal obstruction is CECT
  • CXR erect to rule out perforation
  • Small bowel> 3cm ( suggestive of dilatation), Large bowel > 6 cm (abnormal), Caecum > 9cm (risk of perforation)
  • Best X-ray view to look at intestinal obstruction- supine radiograph
  • Small bowel obstruction showing multiple air-fluid levels or string of beads on erect film

Explanation of other options:

Ileum (Option B) and Jejunum (Option C):- In small bowel loop obstruction, the dilated bowel loops are situated in the centre and show peculiar features particular to the bowel loops. (jejunal- concertina/plica circularis/valvulae conniventes and featureless- ileum).

Gastric volvulus (Option D) is characterised by Borchardt's triad consisting of unproductive retching, epigastric pain and distention, and the inability to pass a nasogastric tube, and X-ray shows the twisted stomach.

choices.text: Air on either side of the bowel

questions.text: All are components of Rigler's triad except?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The Rigler's triad consists of small-bowel obstruction, pneumobilia, and an ectopic gallstone is virtually pathognomonic for gallstone ileus.
  • "Air on either side of the bowel" refers to the Rigler sign, which is seen in pneumoperitoneum (when both sides of the bowel wall are visible due to free intraperitoneal air), and is not a component of Rigler's triad.

(Options A, B and C explained)

questions.text: What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The given image shows a barium enema study of the large bowel loops.
  • There is a narrowing of the distal rectosigmoid colon and proximal colonic dilation, which is pathognomonic for Hirschsprung disease.
  • This reflects the absence of ganglion cells in the distal colon, resulting in a tonic segment with functional obstruction and dilatation of the proximal, normally innervated colon.

Explanation of other options:

Intestinal obstruction (Option C) shows multiple air-fluid levels or string of beads on erect film and Step ladder pattern, whereas the given image shows narrowing of the distal-most colon and proximal dilation of the colon, suggestive of Hirschsprung disease.

Ileal atresia (Option B) shows a Microcolon seen on barium enema (Apple peel appearance) and Multiple air-fluid levels, whereas the given image shows narrowing of the distal-most colon and proximal dilation of the colon, suggestive of Hirschsprung disease.

Volvulus (Option D): "Coffee-bean sign" on abdominal imaging studies such as ultrasound or CT, indicating the twisting of bowel loops around the mesenteric axis, whereas the given image shows narrowing of the distal-most colon and proximal dilation of the colon, suggestive of Hirschsprung disease.

questions.text: In a patient with abnormal bowel movements, the following barium enema study was done. Identify the following image?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The given barium enema study shows a saw-tooth appearance suggestive of colonic diverticulosis.
  • Both single and double-contrast barium enemas are able to demonstrate diverticula as barium-filled out pouchings.
  • Colonic diverticula are almost all false diverticula, i.e., mucosa herniating through a defect in the muscularis and covered by overlying serosa (where present).
  • Given below is the barium enema study of colonic diverticulosis.

Explanation of other choices:

Celiac disease (Option B) is a T-cell mediated autoimmune chronic gluten intolerance, on CT enteroclysis shows jejunoileal fold pattern reversal and ileal fold thickening.

Carcinoma colon (Option C) shows the typical Apple core sign/napkin ring sign and describes a short segment of irregular circumferential stricture involving the large bowel. The given barium enema study shows a saw-tooth appearance, suggestive of colonic diverticulosis.

Ulcerative colitis (Option D), also known as pancolitis, involves the whole rectum with oedema of even the terminal ileum. On fluoroscopy, it shows-

  • Mucosal granularity is seen with button-shaped ulcers and lead pipe colon.

questions.text: A 70-year-old male with constipation undergoes a barium study. The following image is obtained. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The given clinical scenario, along with the barium study showing apple core sign, is suggestive of carcinoma colon.
  • Apple core sign/napkin ring sign describes a short segment of irregular circumferential stricture involving the large bowel.
  • It has shoulder margins resembling an apple core. The appearance is classically described in contrast to enema studies and is almost always due to a stenosing annular colon carcinoma.

Explanation of other options:

Ulcerative colitis (Option A), also known as pancolitis, involves the whole rectum with oedema of even the terminal ileum.

On fluoroscopy, it shows-

  • Mucosal granularity is seen with button-shaped ulcers.

  • In chronic cases, the bowel becomes featureless with loss of normal haustral markings and lead pipe colon.

Intussusception (Option C) is a condition in which one segment of the intestine "telescopes" inside of another, causing an intestinal obstruction (blockage), it will show a claw sign on barium studies and a target sign on USG, where as the given USG shows cervix sign which is sen in case of IHPS.


Volvulus (Option D): "Coffee-bean sign" on abdominal imaging studies such as ultrasound or CT, indicating the twisting of bowel loops around the mesenteric axis.

questions.text: What is the investigation of choice in a pregnant patient presenting with acute appendicitis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The initial imaging modality of choice in pregnant patients with suspected appendicitis is graded compression ultrasonography, particularly targeting the right lower quadrant.
  • However, in cases where USG is non-diagnostic, MRI is the investigation of choice, as it provides high soft tissue contrast without ionising radiation, making it safe during pregnancy.
  • MRI demonstrates high sensitivity and specificity for diagnosing acute appendicitis and is especially useful in the second and third trimesters when visualisation with USG becomes limited due to uterine enlargement.

Explanation of other options:

Ultrasound (Option A) has the advantage of being pregnancy-safe and easily available, but in cases where USG is non-diagnostic, MRI is the investigation of choice. MRI has high sensitivity and specificity (91.8%, 97.9% respectively) for the diagnosis of acute appendicitis in pregnant patients with clinically suspected appendicitis.

Both NCCT (Option D) and CECT (Option B) use X-rays as a source, so it is not preferred in pregnancy.
